name: Puliyogare
history: Puliyogare, also known as Tamarind Rice, is a traditional South Indian dish particularly popular in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu. It's known for its tangy and spicy flavor, and it's often served during festivals and as prasadam in temples.
description: Puliyogare is a flavorful rice dish made with cooked rice, tamarind extract, and a specific Puliyogare masala comprising spices and peanuts. It's a balance of sour, sweet, and spicy flavors and is often enjoyed as a meal on its own.

instructions.title: Cook Rice
instructions.description: Cook the rice until it's fluffy and set it aside to cool.

instructions.title: Prepare Tamarind Mixture
instructions.description: In a pan, heat sesame oil. Add mustard seeds, asafoetida, dry red chilies, curry leaves, and peanuts. SautÃ© until the peanuts are roasted. Then add tamarind paste, Puliyogare masala, jaggery, and salt. Cook until the mixture thickens.

instructions.title: Mix Rice with Tamarind Mixture
instructions.description: Add the cooked rice to the tamarind mixture and mix well, ensuring the rice is evenly coated with the spices.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Puliyogare hot or at room temperature. It can be accompanied by papad or raita.

tips: Ensure that the rice grains are separate and not mushy for the best texture.
Adjust the amount of tamarind and jaggery to balance the tanginess and sweetness.
variations: Add a handful of roasted cashews for crunch.
Incorporate some green peas or diced carrots for added nutrition and color.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on the stove over low heat, adding a little water if the rice has dried out.

presentationTips: Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a wedge of lemon.
Serve in a traditional brass or copper bowl for an authentic look.
